description: From Middle English conspiren, from Old French conspirer, from Latin conspirare, conspīrō, from con- (combining form of cum (“with”)) + spīrō (“breathe”).

verbs.description: conspire (third-person singular simple present conspires, present participle conspiring, simple past and past participle conspired)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To secretly plot or make plans together, often with the intention to bring bad or illegal results.
(intransitive) To agree, to concur to one end.
examples: The press, the pulpit, and the stage / Conspire to censure and expose our age.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To work together to bring about.
